config.text: What should you do before driving into a tunnel?

choices.label: Switch off your radio
Take off your sunglasses
Close your sunroof
Switch on your windscreen wipers

correct.text: If you're wearing sunglasses, you should remove them before driving into a tunnel. If you don’t, your vision will be restricted, even in tunnels that appear to be well lit.

incorrect.text: If you're wearing sunglasses, you should remove them before driving into a tunnel. If you don’t, your vision will be restricted, even in tunnels that appear to be well lit.

config.text: Which document may the police ask you to produce after you've been involved in a collision?

choices.label: Your vehicle registration document
Your driving licence
Your theory test certificate
Your vehicle service record

correct.text: You must stop if you've been involved in a collision that results in injury or damage. The police may ask to see your driving licence and insurance details at the time or later at a police station.

incorrect.text: You must stop if you've been involved in a collision that results in injury or damage. The police may ask to see your driving licence and insurance details at the time or later at a police station.

config.text: A collision has just happened. An injured person is lying in a busy road. What's the first thing you should do?

choices.label: Treat the person for shock
Warn other traffic
Place them in the recovery position
Make sure the injured person is kept warm

correct.text: The most immediate danger is further collisions and fire. You could warn other traffic by switching on hazard warning lights, displaying an advance warning triangle or sign (but not on a motorway), or by any other means that doesn't put you or others at risk.

incorrect.text: The most immediate danger is further collisions and fire. You could warn other traffic by switching on hazard warning lights, displaying an advance warning triangle or sign (but not on a motorway), or by any other means that doesn't put you or others at risk.

config.text: What should you do if your vehicle has a puncture on a motorway?

choices.label: Drive slowly to the next service area to get assistance
Pull up on the hard shoulder or in an emergency area. Change the wheel as quickly as possible
Pull up on the hard shoulder or in an emergency area and call for assistance
Switch on your hazard warning lights. Stop in your lane

correct.text:
Pull up on the hard shoulder or in an emergency area and call for assistance.
Don't attempt to repair your vehicle while it's on the hard shoulder, because of the risk posed by traffic passing at high speeds.

incorrect.text:
Pull up on the hard shoulder or in an emergency area and call for assistance.
Don't attempt to repair your vehicle while it's on the hard shoulder, because of the risk posed by traffic passing at high speeds.

meta.xref: DES s3, DES s11, DES s15, DES s16, HC r116

config.text: When are you allowed to use hazard warning lights?

choices.label: When stopped and temporarily obstructing traffic
When travelling during darkness without headlights
When parked on double yellow lines to visit a shop
When travelling slowly because you're lost

correct.text:
You mustn't use hazard warning lights while moving, except to warn traffic behind when you slow suddenly on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway.
Never use hazard warning lights to excuse dangerous or illegal parking.

incorrect.text:
You mustn't use hazard warning lights while moving, except to warn traffic behind when you slow suddenly on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway.
Never use hazard warning lights to excuse dangerous or illegal parking.

config.text: After a collision, someone is unconscious in their vehicle. When should you call the emergency services?

choices.label: Only as a last resort
As soon as possible
After you've woken them up
After checking for broken bones

correct.text: It's important to make sure that the emergency services arrive as soon as possible. When a person is unconscious, they could have serious injuries that aren't immediately obvious.

incorrect.text: It's important to make sure that the emergency services arrive as soon as possible. When a person is unconscious, they could have serious injuries that aren't immediately obvious.

config.text: You've broken down on a two-way road. You have a warning triangle. At least how far from your vehicle should you place the warning triangle?

choices.label: 5 metres (16 feet)
25 metres (82 feet)
45 metres (147 feet)
100 metres (328 feet)

correct.text: Advance warning triangles fold flat and don’t take up much room. Use one to warn other road users if your vehicle has broken down or if there has been an incident. Place it at least 45 metres (147 feet) behind your vehicle (or the incident), on the same side of the road or verge. Place it further back if the scene is hidden by, for example, a bend, hill or dip in the road. Don’t use warning triangles on motorways.

incorrect.text: Advance warning triangles fold flat and don’t take up much room. Use one to warn other road users if your vehicle has broken down or if there has been an incident. Place it at least 45 metres (147 feet) behind your vehicle (or the incident), on the same side of the road or verge. Place it further back if the scene is hidden by, for example, a bend, hill or dip in the road. Don’t use warning triangles on motorways.

config.text: An injured motorcyclist is lying unconscious in the road. The traffic has stopped and there's no further danger. What could you do to help?

choices.label: Remove their safety helmet
Seek medical assistance
Move the person off the road
Remove their leather jacket

correct.text: If someone has been injured, the sooner proper medical attention is given the better. Ask someone to phone for help or do it yourself. An injured person should only be moved if they're in further danger. An injured motorcyclist's helmet shouldn't be removed unless it's essential.

incorrect.text: If someone has been injured, the sooner proper medical attention is given the better. Ask someone to phone for help or do it yourself. An injured person should only be moved if they're in further danger. An injured motorcyclist's helmet shouldn't be removed unless it's essential.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r299, KYTS p30

config.text: What should you do first if your vehicle has broken down on an automatic railway level crossing?

choices.label: Get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing
Telephone your vehicle recovery service to move it
Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains
Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible

correct.text: First, get yourself and anyone else well away from the crossing. If there's a railway telephone, use that to get instructions from the signal operator. Then, if there's time, move the vehicle clear of the crossing.

incorrect.text: First, get yourself and anyone else well away from the crossing. If there's a railway telephone, use that to get instructions from the signal operator. Then, if there's time, move the vehicle clear of the crossing.

config.text: At an incident, someone is unconscious and you want to help. What would be the first thing to check?

choices.label: Whether their vehicle is insured
Whether they have any allergies
Whether they're comfortable
Whether their airway is open

correct.text: Remember this procedure by saying DR ABC. This stands for Danger, Response, Airway, Breathing, Circulation. Give whatever first aid you can and stay with the injured person until a medical professional takes over.

incorrect.text: Remember this procedure by saying DR ABC. This stands for Danger, Response, Airway, Breathing, Circulation. Give whatever first aid you can and stay with the injured person until a medical professional takes over.

config.text: What should you do if your vehicle catches fire while you're driving through a tunnel?

choices.label: Leave it where it is, with the engine running
Pull up, then walk to an emergency telephone
Park it away from the carriageway
Drive it out of the tunnel if it's safe to do so

correct.text: If it’s possible, and you can do so without causing further danger, it may be safer to drive a vehicle that's on fire out of a tunnel. The greatest danger in a tunnel fire is smoke and suffocation.

incorrect.text: If it’s possible, and you can do so without causing further danger, it may be safer to drive a vehicle that's on fire out of a tunnel. The greatest danger in a tunnel fire is smoke and suffocation.

config.text: Following a collision, a person has been injured. What would be a warning sign for shock?

choices.label: Flushed complexion
Warm dry skin
Slow pulse
Rapid shallow breathing

correct.text:
The effects of shock may not be immediately obvious. Warning signs to look for include
  • a rapid pulse
  • sweating
  • pale grey skin
  • rapid shallow breathing.

incorrect.text:
The effects of shock may not be immediately obvious. Warning signs to look for include
  • a rapid pulse
  • sweating
  • pale grey skin
  • rapid shallow breathing.

config.text: At an incident, how could you help a casualty who has stopped breathing?

choices.label: Keep their head tilted forwards as far as possible
Follow the DR ABC code
Raise their legs to help with circulation
Try to give them something to drink

correct.text: The DR ABC code has been devised by medical experts to give the best outcome until the emergency services arrive and take care of casualties.

incorrect.text: The DR ABC code has been devised by medical experts to give the best outcome until the emergency services arrive and take care of casualties.

config.text: You're driving on the motorway. What should you do if luggage falls from your vehicle?

choices.label: Stop at the next emergency telephone and report the incident
Stop on the motorway and switch on hazard warning lights while you pick it up
Walk back up the motorway to pick it up
Pull up on the hard shoulder and wave traffic down

correct.text: If any object falls onto the motorway carriageway from your vehicle, pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and call for assistance. Don’t stop on the carriageway or attempt to retrieve anything.

incorrect.text: If any object falls onto the motorway carriageway from your vehicle, pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and call for assistance. Don’t stop on the carriageway or attempt to retrieve anything.

config.text: What should you do if an instrument panel warning light comes on while you're driving?

choices.label: Continue if the engine sounds all right
Hope that it's just a temporary electrical fault
Deal with the problem when there's more time
Check out the problem quickly and safely

correct.text: Make sure you know what the different warning lights mean. An illuminated warning light could mean that your car is unsafe to drive. If you aren't sure about the problem, get a qualified mechanic to check it.

incorrect.text: Make sure you know what the different warning lights mean. An illuminated warning light could mean that your car is unsafe to drive. If you aren't sure about the problem, get a qualified mechanic to check it.

config.text: Which sign shows that a tanker is carrying dangerous goods?

correct.text: Tankers will display a hazard warning plate on the side and rear of the vehicle. Details of hazard warning symbols are given in The Highway Code. If a tanker is involved in a collision, you may need to report the tanker's hazard labelling to the emergency services.

incorrect.text: Tankers will display a hazard warning plate on the side and rear of the vehicle. Details of hazard warning symbols are given in The Highway Code. If a tanker is involved in a collision, you may need to report the tanker's hazard labelling to the emergency services.

config.text: You're going through a long tunnel. What will warn you of congestion or an incident ahead?

choices.label: Hazard warning lines
Other drivers flashing their lights
Variable message signs
Areas with hatch markings

correct.text: Follow the instructions given by the signs or by tunnel officials. In congested tunnels, a minor incident can soon turn into a major one, with serious or even fatal results.

incorrect.text: Follow the instructions given by the signs or by tunnel officials. In congested tunnels, a minor incident can soon turn into a major one, with serious or even fatal results.

config.text: Your vehicle has stalled in the middle of a level crossing. What should you do if the warning bells start to ring while you're trying to restart the engine?

choices.label: Get out of the car and clear of the crossing
Run down the track to warn the signal operator
Carry on trying to restart the engine
Push the vehicle clear of the crossing

correct.text: If the warning bells ring, leave the vehicle and get any passengers well clear of the crossing immediately.

incorrect.text: If the warning bells ring, leave the vehicle and get any passengers well clear of the crossing immediately.

config.text: What should you do if a tyre bursts while you're driving?

choices.label: Pull on the parking brake
Brake as quickly as possible
Pull up slowly at the side of the road
Continue on at a normal speed

correct.text: A tyre bursting can lead to a loss of control, especially if you're travelling at high speed. Using the correct procedure should help you to stop the vehicle safely.

incorrect.text: A tyre bursting can lead to a loss of control, especially if you're travelling at high speed. Using the correct procedure should help you to stop the vehicle safely.

config.text: You lose control of your car and damage a garden wall. What must you do if the property owner isn't available?

choices.label: Report the incident to the police within 24 hours
Go back to tell the house owner the next day
Report the incident to your insurance company when you get home
Find someone in the area to tell them about it immediately

correct.text: If the property owner isn't available at the time, you must inform the police about the incident. This should be done as soon as possible, and in any case within 24 hours.

incorrect.text: If the property owner isn't available at the time, you must inform the police about the incident. This should be done as soon as possible, and in any case within 24 hours.

config.text: An injured person has been placed in the recovery position. They're unconscious but breathing normally. What else should be done?

choices.label: Press firmly between their shoulders
Place their arms by their side
Give them a hot sweet drink
Check their airway remains open

correct.text: After a casualty has been placed in the recovery position, make sure their airway remains open and monitor their condition until medical help arrives. Where possible, don't move a casualty unless there's further danger.

incorrect.text: After a casualty has been placed in the recovery position, make sure their airway remains open and monitor their condition until medical help arrives. Where possible, don't move a casualty unless there's further danger.

config.text: At an incident, a casualty is unconscious but breathing. When should you move them?

choices.label: When an ambulance is on its way
When bystanders tell you to move them
When there's a risk of further danger
When bystanders offer to help you

correct.text: Don't move a casualty unless there's further danger; for example, from other traffic or fire. They may have unseen or internal injuries. Moving them unnecessarily could cause further injury. Don't remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it's essential.

incorrect.text: Don't move a casualty unless there's further danger; for example, from other traffic or fire. They may have unseen or internal injuries. Moving them unnecessarily could cause further injury. Don't remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it's essential.

config.text: You're the first person to arrive at an incident where people are badly injured. You've switched on your hazard warning lights and checked all engines are stopped. What else should you do?

choices.label: Make sure that an ambulance has been called
Stop other cars and ask the drivers for help
Try and get people who are injured to drink something
Move the people who are injured clear of their vehicles

correct.text: If you're the first to arrive at a crash scene, the first concerns are the risk of further collision and fire. Ensuring that vehicle engines are switched off will reduce the risk of fire. Use hazard warning lights so that other traffic knows there's a need for caution. Make sure the emergency services are contacted; don't assume it's already been done.

incorrect.text: If you're the first to arrive at a crash scene, the first concerns are the risk of further collision and fire. Ensuring that vehicle engines are switched off will reduce the risk of fire. Use hazard warning lights so that other traffic knows there's a need for caution. Make sure the emergency services are contacted; don't assume it's already been done.

config.text: There's been a collision. How can you help a driver who's suffering from shock?

choices.label: Give them a drink
Reassure them confidently
Ask who caused the incident
Offer them a cigarette

correct.text: A casualty suffering from shock may have injuries that aren't immediately obvious. Call the emergency services, then stay with the person in shock, offering reassurance until the experts arrive.

incorrect.text: A casualty suffering from shock may have injuries that aren't immediately obvious. Call the emergency services, then stay with the person in shock, offering reassurance until the experts arrive.

config.text: You're at the scene of an incident. How could you help someone who's suffering from shock?

choices.label: Reassure them confidently
Offer them a cigarette
Give them a warm drink
Offer them some food

correct.text: If someone is suffering from shock, try to keep them warm and as comfortable as you can. Don't give them anything to eat or drink but reassure them confidently and try not to leave them alone.

incorrect.text: If someone is suffering from shock, try to keep them warm and as comfortable as you can. Don't give them anything to eat or drink but reassure them confidently and try not to leave them alone.

config.text: What should you do if you have to stop while you're going through a congested tunnel?

choices.label: Pull up very close to the vehicle in front to save space
Ignore any message signs, as they're never up to date
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front
Make a U-turn and find another route

correct.text: It’s important to keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front at all times. This still applies in congested tunnels, even if you're moving very slowly or have stopped. If the vehicle in front breaks down, you may need room to manoeuvre past it.

incorrect.text: It’s important to keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front at all times. This still applies in congested tunnels, even if you're moving very slowly or have stopped. If the vehicle in front breaks down, you may need room to manoeuvre past it.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r299, KYTS p30

config.text: Your car breaks down on a level crossing. What's the first thing you should do?

choices.label: Tell drivers behind what's happened
Leave your vehicle and get everyone clear
Walk down the track and signal the next train
Stay in your car until you're told to move

correct.text: If your vehicle breaks down on a level crossing, your first priority is to get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing. Then use the railway telephone, if there is one, to tell the signal operator. If you have time before the train arrives, move the vehicle clear of the crossing, but only do this if the alarm signals aren't activated.

incorrect.text: If your vehicle breaks down on a level crossing, your first priority is to get everyone out of the vehicle and clear of the crossing. Then use the railway telephone, if there is one, to tell the signal operator. If you have time before the train arrives, move the vehicle clear of the crossing, but only do this if the alarm signals aren't activated.

config.text: You arrive at an incident. A pedestrian is bleeding heavily from a leg wound. The leg isn't broken and there's nothing in the wound. How could you help?

choices.label: Dab the wound to stop the bleeding
Keep the casualty's legs flat on the ground
Give them a warm drink
Apply firm pressure over the wound

correct.text: You should protect yourself from exposure to blood, and then apply firm pressure over the wound to stem the flow of blood. As soon as practical, fasten a pad to the wound with a bandage or length of cloth. Use the cleanest material available.

incorrect.text: You should protect yourself from exposure to blood, and then apply firm pressure over the wound to stem the flow of blood. As soon as practical, fasten a pad to the wound with a bandage or length of cloth. Use the cleanest material available.

config.text: There's been a collision. A motorcyclist is lying injured and unconscious. Why should you only remove their helmet if it's essential?

choices.label: They might not want you to remove it
Removing it could make any injuries worse
Removing it could let them get cold
You could scratch the helmet as you remove it

correct.text: When someone is injured, any movement that isn't absolutely necessary should be avoided, since it could make the injuries worse. Unless it's essential to remove a motorcyclist's helmet, it's generally safer to leave it in place.

incorrect.text: When someone is injured, any movement that isn't absolutely necessary should be avoided, since it could make the injuries worse. Unless it's essential to remove a motorcyclist's helmet, it's generally safer to leave it in place.

config.text: What could you do to help injured people at an incident?

choices.label: Keep them warm and comfortable
Give them something to eat
Keep them on the move by walking them around
Give them a warm drink

correct.text: There are a number of things you can do to help, even without expert training. Be aware of further danger from other traffic and fire; make sure the area is safe. People may be in shock. Don't give them anything to eat or drink. Keep them warm and comfortable and reassure them. Don't move injured people unless there's a risk of further danger.

incorrect.text: There are a number of things you can do to help, even without expert training. Be aware of further danger from other traffic and fire; make sure the area is safe. People may be in shock. Don't give them anything to eat or drink. Keep them warm and comfortable and reassure them. Don't move injured people unless there's a risk of further danger.

config.text: What's the first thing you must do if you have a collision while you're driving your car?

choices.label: Stop only if someone waves at you
Call the emergency services
Stop at the scene of the incident
Call your insurance company

correct.text: If you're in a collision that causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property, by law you must stop. Give your name, the vehicle owner’s name and address, and the vehicle’s registration number to anyone who has reasonable grounds for requesting them.

incorrect.text: If you're in a collision that causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property, by law you must stop. Give your name, the vehicle owner’s name and address, and the vehicle’s registration number to anyone who has reasonable grounds for requesting them.

config.text: A casualty isn't breathing normally and needs CPR. At what rate should you press down and release on the centre of their chest?

choices.label: 10 times per minute
120 times per minute
60 times per minute
240 times per minute

correct.text: If a casualty isn't breathing normally, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may be needed to maintain circulation. Place two hands on the centre of the chest and press down hard and fast – around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

incorrect.text: If a casualty isn't breathing normally, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may be needed to maintain circulation. Place two hands on the centre of the chest and press down hard and fast – around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

config.text: What should you do if your vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?

choices.label: Stay in your vehicle and wait for the police
Stand in the lane behind your vehicle to warn others
Stand in front of your vehicle to warn oncoming drivers
Switch on hazard warning lights, then go and call for help

correct.text: A broken-down vehicle in a tunnel can cause serious congestion and danger to other road users. If your vehicle breaks down, get help without delay. Switch on your hazard warning lights, then go to an emergency telephone to call for help.

incorrect.text: A broken-down vehicle in a tunnel can cause serious congestion and danger to other road users. If your vehicle breaks down, get help without delay. Switch on your hazard warning lights, then go to an emergency telephone to call for help.

config.text: An adult casualty isn't breathing. To maintain circulation, CPR should be given. What's the correct depth to press down on their chest?

choices.label: 1 to 2 centimetres
5 to 6 centimetres
10 to 15 centimetres
15 to 20 centimetres

correct.text: An adult casualty isn't breathing normally. To maintain circulation, place two hands on the centre of the chest. Then press down hard and fast – around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

incorrect.text: An adult casualty isn't breathing normally. To maintain circulation, place two hands on the centre of the chest. Then press down hard and fast – around 5–6 centimetres and about twice a second.

config.text: At an incident, someone is suffering from severe burns. How could you help them?

choices.label: Apply lotions to the injury
Burst any blisters
Remove anything sticking to the burns
Douse the burns with clean, cool water

correct.text: Your priority is to cool the burns with clean, cool water. Its coolness will help take the heat out of the burns and relieve the pain. Keep the wound doused for at least 20 minutes. If blisters appear, don't attempt to burst them, as this could lead to infection.

incorrect.text: Your priority is to cool the burns with clean, cool water. Its coolness will help take the heat out of the burns and relieve the pain. Keep the wound doused for at least 20 minutes. If blisters appear, don't attempt to burst them, as this could lead to infection.

config.text: What information should you share if you’re involved in a collision that causes damage to another vehicle?

choices.label: Your occupation and reason for your journey
Your name, address and vehicle registration number
Your national insurance number
Your internet service provider

correct.text: Try to keep calm and don’t rush. Make sure that you've shared all the relevant details with the other driver before you leave the scene. If possible, take pictures and note the positions of all the vehicles involved.

incorrect.text: Try to keep calm and don’t rush. Make sure that you've shared all the relevant details with the other driver before you leave the scene. If possible, take pictures and note the positions of all the vehicles involved.

config.text: You arrive at an incident. There's no danger from fire or further collisions and the emergency services have been called. What's your first priority when attending to an unconscious motorcyclist?

choices.label: Check whether they're breathing normally
Check whether they're bleeding
Check whether they have any broken bones
Check whether they have any bruising

correct.text: At the scene of an incident, always be aware of danger from further collisions or fire. The first priority when dealing with an unconscious person is to ensure they can breathe. This may involve clearing their airway if you can see an obstruction or if they're having difficulty breathing.

incorrect.text: At the scene of an incident, always be aware of danger from further collisions or fire. The first priority when dealing with an unconscious person is to ensure they can breathe. This may involve clearing their airway if you can see an obstruction or if they're having difficulty breathing.

config.text: What should you do if you see a large box fall from a lorry onto the motorway?

choices.label: Go to the next emergency telephone and report the hazard
Catch up with the lorry and try to get the driver's attention
Stop close to the box until the police arrive
Pull over to the hard shoulder, then remove the box

correct.text: Lorry drivers can be unaware of objects falling from their vehicles. If you see something fall onto a motorway, look to see if the driver pulls over. If they don't stop, don't attempt to retrieve the object yourself. Pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and report the hazard.

incorrect.text: Lorry drivers can be unaware of objects falling from their vehicles. If you see something fall onto a motorway, look to see if the driver pulls over. If they don't stop, don't attempt to retrieve the object yourself. Pull onto the hard shoulder near an emergency telephone and report the hazard.

config.text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. The rider is injured. When should their helmet be removed?

choices.label: Only when it's essential
Always straight away
Only when the motorcyclist asks
Always, unless they're in shock

correct.text: Don't remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it's essential. Remember they may be suffering from shock. Don't give them anything to eat or drink, but do reassure them confidently.

incorrect.text: Don't remove a motorcyclist's helmet unless it's essential. Remember they may be suffering from shock. Don't give them anything to eat or drink, but do reassure them confidently.

config.text: You're on a motorway. When can you use hazard warning lights?

choices.label: When a vehicle is following too closely
When you slow down quickly because of danger ahead
When you're being towed by another vehicle
When you're using the hard shoulder as a running lane

correct.text: Briefly using your hazard warning lights will warn the traffic behind you that there's a hazard ahead. Turn them off again when following drivers have seen and responded to your signal.

incorrect.text: Briefly using your hazard warning lights will warn the traffic behind you that there's a hazard ahead. Turn them off again when following drivers have seen and responded to your signal.

config.text: What should you do to reduce the risk of your vehicle catching fire?

choices.label: Keep water levels above maximum
Check out any strong smell of fuel
Avoid driving with a full tank of fuel
Use fuel additives

correct.text:
The fuel in your vehicle can be a dangerous fire hazard. If you smell fuel, check out where it's coming from. Never
  • use a naked flame near the vehicle if you can smell fuel
  • smoke when refuelling your vehicle.

incorrect.text:
The fuel in your vehicle can be a dangerous fire hazard. If you smell fuel, check out where it's coming from. Never
  • use a naked flame near the vehicle if you can smell fuel
  • smoke when refuelling your vehicle.

config.text: You arrive at the scene of a crash where someone is bleeding heavily from a wound in their arm. Nothing is embedded in the wound. What could you do to help?

choices.label: Walk them around and keep them talking
Dab the wound
Get them a drink
Apply pressure over the wound

correct.text: If possible, lay the casualty down. Protect yourself from exposure to blood and, when you're sure there's nothing in the wound, apply firm pressure using clean material.

incorrect.text: If possible, lay the casualty down. Protect yourself from exposure to blood and, when you're sure there's nothing in the wound, apply firm pressure using clean material.

config.text: At an incident, it's important to look after any casualties. What should you do with them when the area is safe?

choices.label: Move them away from the vehicles
Ask them how it happened
Give them something to eat
Keep them where they are

correct.text: When the area is safe and there's no danger from other traffic or fire, it's better not to move casualties. Moving them may cause further injury.

incorrect.text: When the area is safe and there's no danger from other traffic or fire, it's better not to move casualties. Moving them may cause further injury.

config.text: Which lights should you use when you're driving in a tunnel?

choices.label: Sidelights
Front spotlights
Dipped headlights
Rear fog lights

correct.text:
Before entering a tunnel, you should switch on your dipped headlights, as this will allow you to see and be seen. In many tunnels, it's a legal requirement.
Don’t wear sunglasses while you're driving in a tunnel.

incorrect.text:
Before entering a tunnel, you should switch on your dipped headlights, as this will allow you to see and be seen. In many tunnels, it's a legal requirement.
Don’t wear sunglasses while you're driving in a tunnel.

config.text: You arrive at the scene of a motorcycle crash. No other vehicle is involved. The rider is unconscious and lying in the middle of the road. What's the first thing you should do at the scene?

choices.label: Move the rider out of the road
Warn other traffic
Clear the road of debris
Give the rider reassurance

correct.text: The motorcyclist is in an extremely vulnerable position, exposed to further danger from traffic. Approaching vehicles need advance warning in order to slow down and safely take avoiding action or stop. Don't put yourself or anyone else at risk. Use the hazard warning lights on your vehicle to alert other road users to the danger.

incorrect.text: The motorcyclist is in an extremely vulnerable position, exposed to further danger from traffic. Approaching vehicles need advance warning in order to slow down and safely take avoiding action or stop. Don't put yourself or anyone else at risk. Use the hazard warning lights on your vehicle to alert other road users to the danger.

config.text: At an incident, how could you help a small child who isn't breathing?

choices.label: Find their parents and explain what's happening
Open their airway and begin CPR
Put them in the recovery position and slap their back
Talk to them confidently until an ambulance arrives

correct.text: If a young child has stopped breathing, first check that their airway is open and then begin CPR. With a young child, you may only need to use one hand and you shouldn't press down as far as you would with an adult. Continue the procedure until the child is breathing again or until a medical professional takes over.

incorrect.text: If a young child has stopped breathing, first check that their airway is open and then begin CPR. With a young child, you may only need to use one hand and you shouldn't press down as far as you would with an adult. Continue the procedure until the child is breathing again or until a medical professional takes over.

config.text: At an incident, a casualty isn't breathing. What should you do while helping them to start breathing again?

choices.label: Put their arms across their chest
Shake them firmly
Roll them onto their side
Open their airway

correct.text: It's important to ensure that the airway is open before you start CPR. To open the casualty's airway, place your fingers under their chin and lift it forward.

incorrect.text: It's important to ensure that the airway is open before you start CPR. To open the casualty's airway, place your fingers under their chin and lift it forward.

config.text: You're at an incident. What could you do to help an unconscious casualty?

choices.label: Take photographs of the scene
Check that they're breathing normally
Move them to somewhere more comfortable
Splash their face with cool water

correct.text: If a casualty is unconscious, you need to check that they're breathing normally. Look for chest movements, look and listen for breathing, and feel for breath on your cheek.

incorrect.text: If a casualty is unconscious, you need to check that they're breathing normally. Look for chest movements, look and listen for breathing, and feel for breath on your cheek.
